deliberation: Superscription giving author, lineage, priestly status, and geographic location. All terms function in a straightforward historical-descriptive way. Considered whether “words of Jeremiah” is metonymic for the whole book, but this is the literal content (his prophetic words), not an image-based figure.

Formulaic prophetic expression “the word of YHWH came to him.” Considered anthropomorphism and personification, but the main device is lexical: ‘word’ (singular) standing for the whole complex revelation. That is a metonymy rather than a vivid metaphor.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to him
ground: both a ‘word’ and a prophetic message convey content from speaker to hearer
communication of content
communication in general
posture: stresses that the initiative and content come from GOD, not Jeremiah
instances.explanation: “Word” (singular) stands metonymically for the full, multi-faceted revelation from GOD, not literally a single lexical item.

deliberation: Chronological notice ending with “until the exile of Jerusalem.” Here “Jerusalem” stands for its inhabitants being exiled, a standard city-for-people metonymy.

ground: a city is identified with its inhabitants; speaking of the city’s exile evokes the people’s fate
representational link (place for people)
metonymic relations in discourse
posture: underscores the totality of the disaster, enveloping the whole city-community
instances.explanation: The city name “Jerusalem” is used metonymically for its people who were exiled.

deliberation: First-person form of the standard prophetic formula “the word of YHWH came to me.” As in v.2, ‘word’ stands for the entire revelatory message, a metonymy rather than a concrete single word.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a ‘word’ as a discrete item of speech
ground: both describe a communicative act delivering content from GOD to Jeremiah
communication and message-ness
communication in general
posture: presents Jeremiah as passive recipient of an authoritative message
instances.explanation: “Word” is used metonymically for the fuller prophetic message that Jeremiah receives.

deliberation: The verse speaks of GOD’s foreknowledge, forming in the womb, consecration, and appointment. These are theological claims but expressed straightforwardly without an image-based comparison. Considered whether ‘knew’ is metaphorical for ‘chose’, but in Hebrew idiom yādaʿ commonly includes that nuance literally. No clear figurative language.

Jeremiah’s protest: “I do not know how to speak, for I am a boy.” The phrase “I do not know how to speak” is idiomatic for lack of rhetorical competence, not literal inability to speak at all, and is somewhat hyperbolic self-deprecation.

instances.english_text: I don’t know how to speak
target: Jeremiah’s lack of training or confidence in public speaking
vehicle: total ignorance of how to speak at all
ground: both express an inability to perform competent, authoritative speech
insufficiency for eloquent or authoritative speaking
competence/incompetence
posture: self-effacing objection to a divine call
instances.explanation: The idiom exaggerates Jeremiah’s deficiency: he can speak, but claims not to ‘know how to speak’ in the sense of being unfit as a public prophetic speaker.

deliberation: GOD counters Jeremiah’s objection: “Do not say, ‘I am a boy.’” The verse speaks directly about going and speaking what GOD commands. No image-based comparison or idiom beyond ordinary sending and commanding language.

Promise of divine presence and deliverance: “for I am with you to deliver you.” Considered whether “with you” is metaphorical spatial language for support, but this is standard covenantal phrasing and functions literally in the theological frame. No distinct figurative image is developed.

A commissioning vision: GOD stretches out his hand and touches Jeremiah’s mouth, and declares, “I have put my words in your mouth.” Both the anthropomorphic ‘hand’ and the insertion of ‘words’ into a mouth are figurative depictions of prophetic inspiration.

instances.english_text: GOD reached out and touched my mouth
target: GOD’s act of empowering Jeremiah to speak prophetically
vehicle: a human hand extended to touch someone’s mouth
ground: both involve a direct, personal action that confers ability or authorization
immediate impartation of capacity and authority
empowerment/transfer actions
posture: portrays an intimate yet authoritative divine initiative toward Jeremiah
instances.explanation: GOD is portrayed anthropomorphically as having a hand and physically touching Jeremiah’s mouth—a personification that pictures the invisible act of inspiration.

instances.english_text: Herewith I put My words into your mouth
target: Jeremiah’s reception of and ability to proclaim GOD’s message
vehicle: placing physical ‘words’ into a physical mouth
ground: both result in particular words coming from Jeremiah’s mouth, determined by the giver
transfer and internalization of verbal content
communication and embodiment
posture: emphasizes Jeremiah’s total dependence on words given from outside himself
instances.explanation: Depicts Jeremiah’s inspiration as if GOD were placing tangible ‘words’ inside his mouth. ‘Words’ also stand metonymically for the entire prophetic message.

deliberation: Jeremiah is set ‘over nations and kingdoms’ with a sixfold series of verbs: uproot, pull down, destroy, overthrow, build, plant. These are not literal physical actions by Jeremiah but metaphorical of the impact of his prophetic word in judgment and restoration.

instances.hebrew_text: לִנְתּוֹשׁ וְלִנְתֹּץ וּלְהַאֲבִיד וְלַהֲרֹס לִבְנוֹת וְלִנְטֹעַ
instances.english_text: To uproot and to pull down, To destroy and to overthrow, To build and to plant
target: the destructive and restorative effects of Jeremiah’s prophetic ministry on nations and kingdoms
history under divine judgment and renewal
vehicle: agricultural and architectural actions of uprooting, demolishing, building, and planting
violent removal and constructive establishment activities
ground: both prophetic words and such physical actions can dismantle existing structures and establish new ones
radical deconstruction and subsequent reconstruction
processes of judgment and restoration
posture: presents Jeremiah’s ministry as powerful, invasive, but ultimately constructive under GOD’s direction
instances.explanation: Jeremiah’s spoken prophecies are portrayed metaphorically as if they were acts of uprooting, tearing down, destroying, overthrowing, building, and planting among the nations.

deliberation: Jeremiah reports what he literally sees in the vision: ‘a branch/rod of an almond tree.’ The figurative significance emerges only in v.12 with the wordplay. In this verse by itself the description is straightforward narrative of a seen object.

GOD interprets the almond-rod vision with a pun: shaqēd (almond) / shōqēd (watchful). The key figurative element is GOD described as ‘watching over’ His word to perform it—an anthropomorphic watchman metaphor, plus deliberate wordplay.

instances.english_text: For I am watchful over My word to bring it to pass
target: GOD’s faithfulness to carry out His pronouncements
vehicle: a watchman or guardian vigilantly overseeing something
ground: both vigilant watching and divine faithfulness involve careful attention leading to timely action
alert commitment to ensure an outcome
responsible oversight
posture: reassures Jeremiah that GOD is actively, attentively ensuring the fulfillment of His word
instances.explanation: GOD portrays Himself like a watchman guarding His word to execute it. The verb ‘shōqēd’ echoes ‘shaqēd’ (almond), forming a pun that ties the literal almond rod to the figurative ‘watching’.

deliberation: Jeremiah sees ‘a boiling pot, tipped away from the north.’ In context it is a symbolic vision; the pot’s figurative meaning is explained in v.14 as disaster from the north. The boiling, tilting pot functions as a metaphorical vehicle for impending northern judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: סִיר נָפוּחַ אֲנִי רֹאֶה וּפָנָיו מִפְּנֵי צָפוֹנָה
instances.english_text: I see a steaming pot, tipped away from the north
target: the imminent invasion and calamity coming from the north
vehicle: a boiling pot whose ‘face’ is turned from the north, as if about to spill
unstable, overheated vessel about to pour out contents
ground: both depict something unstable and ready to pour out destructive force from a particular direction
imminent overflow of danger from a source region
onset of crisis/judgment
posture: communicates an ominous, threatening situation poised to break upon the land
instances.explanation: The boiling pot is a symbolic picture of northern disaster about to pour down upon Judah, functioning as a metaphor in vision form.

deliberation: GOD interprets the vision: “From the north shall disaster break loose (be opened) upon all the inhabitants of the land.” The verb ‘be opened’ applied to ‘evil/disaster’ pictures calamity as something like a gate or container suddenly opened, a metaphorical onset image closely tied to the pot vision.

instances.hebrew_text: מִצָּפוֹן תִּפָּתַח הָרָעָה עַל כָּל־יֹשְׁבֵי הָאָרֶץ
instances.english_text: From the north shall disaster break loose upon all the inhabitants of the land
target: the eruption of military disaster across the land
vehicle: something (like a door, gate, or container) being opened, releasing what is inside
act of opening that unleashes contents
ground: both depict a previously restrained force suddenly unleashed over a wide area
sudden, uncontrollable outbreak
dynamics of release/breakout
posture: heightens a sense of inevitability and sweeping scope of the coming calamity
instances.explanation: Disaster is described as if it were a thing that can be ‘opened’ from the north, personifying calamity and using a metaphor of release.

deliberation: GOD calls ‘all the families of the kingdoms of the north’ and says each will ‘set his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem.’ The ‘throne’ stands metonymically for royal authority and judicial/governmental presence imposed upon the city.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתְנוּ אִישׁ כִּסְאוֹ פֶּתַח שַׁעֲרֵי יְרוּשָׁלִַם
instances.english_text: and they shall each set up a throne before the gates of Jerusalem
target: foreign kings’ exercise of dominion and judgment over Jerusalem
vehicle: a throne placed at the gates of a city
ground: a throne concretely embodies the presence and authority of a ruler
symbolic representation of governance and judgment
symbolism of objects
posture: depicts humiliating subjugation of Jerusalem under foreign rulers
instances.explanation: The ‘throne’ is used metonymically for the kings’ authority and judicial presence established at Jerusalem’s gates.

deliberation: GOD will speak His judgments because they have forsaken Him and ‘worshiped the works of their hands.’ This phrase is a standard metonymy for man-made idols—stressing their human manufacture rather than using a fresh metaphor.

instances.english_text: And worshiped the works of their hands
target: the idols Israel has made and reveres
vehicle: “works of their hands” as a phrase for what they have crafted
ground: the idols are in fact things they made with their own hands; the product stands for the cult object
producer–product relationship
metonymic representation
posture: denigrates idols by emphasizing their purely human origin
instances.explanation: The expression ‘works of their hands’ stands metonymically for their idols, highlighting that what they worship is their own manufactured product.

deliberation: Two figurative elements: (1) ‘Gird up your loins’ is a common Hebrew idiom deriving from clothing practice, metaphorical for mental/physical readiness. (2) ‘Do not be shattered before them, lest I shatter you before them’ uses the verb ‘shatter’ metaphorically of psychological collapse and humiliating defeat.

target: Jeremiah’s inner preparedness and resolve for his prophetic task
vehicle: tightening one’s belt and gathering up long garments for action
ground: both bodily girding and psychological readiness involve intentional preparation for demanding activity
making oneself ready for strenuous effort
readiness for action
posture: exhorts Jeremiah to active, energetic obedience
instances.explanation: An idiom based on literal clothing practice, metaphorically commanding Jeremiah to be mentally and spiritually ready for vigorous action.

instances.english_text: Do not break down before them, Lest I break you before them
target: Jeremiah’s potential fear and public loss of nerve
vehicle: an object being shattered or broken
physical fragmentation of a solid object
ground: both physical shattering and psychological collapse involve loss of integrity and strength
destruction of wholeness leading to dysfunction and disgrace
states of ruin/failure
posture: warns Jeremiah that cowardice will lead to divinely enforced humiliation commensurate with his calling
instances.explanation: The verb ‘to be shattered/break’ is used metaphorically for emotional collapse and public humiliation, with a wordplay between Jeremiah’s fear and GOD’s disciplinary ‘breaking’.

deliberation: Jeremiah is compared successively to a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls. These are three intertwined metaphors for his divinely granted resilience and unassailable stance against societal opposition.

instances.english_text: I make you this day a fortified city
target: Jeremiah’s spiritual and psychological stability under attack
ground: both an unbreached city and Jeremiah withstand hostile assault
impenetrability and capacity to endure siege
defense under attack
posture: assures Jeremiah of divinely granted strength greater than that of his opponents
instances.explanation: GOD likens Jeremiah to a fortified city, emphasizing that he will be able to withstand the assaults of the surrounding authorities and populace.

target: Jeremiah’s firmness and unbending support for GOD’s word
ground: both an iron pillar and Jeremiah are envisaged as unable to be bent or broken under weight
strength, rigidity, and support
stability and endurance
posture: presents Jeremiah as a stable support structure within a collapsing society
instances.explanation: Jeremiah is metaphorically called an ‘iron pillar,’ highlighting unyielding strength and support for the divine message.

target: Jeremiah’s protective separation from and resistance to hostile forces
ground: bronze walls and Jeremiah both function as barriers that cannot be easily breached
durability and protective function
defense against attacks
posture: further reinforces the image of invulnerability granted by GOD against societal opposition
instances.explanation: By calling Jeremiah ‘bronze walls,’ GOD depicts him as an unassailable barrier against the assaults of kings, officials, priests, and people.

deliberation: The adversaries will ‘fight against’ Jeremiah but not ‘overcome’ him. The verb ‘fight’ draws on warfare imagery for the conflict between Jeremiah and his opponents. While hostility will include physical elements, the wording generalizes all opposition as battle—an underlying conflict-as-war metaphor.

instances.english_text: They will attack you, But they shall not overcome you
target: the social, verbal, and legal opposition Jeremiah will face
hostility and attempts to silence or destroy him
vehicle: literal warfare—fighting and prevailing over an enemy
ground: both warfare and Jeremiah’s opposition involve organized attempts to defeat and overpower an opponent
intense, goal-directed struggle for dominance
conflict dynamics
posture: acknowledges real, severe conflict but promises divinely guaranteed ultimate ‘victory’ for Jeremiah
instances.explanation: Opposition to Jeremiah is cast in the language of battle, presenting his prophetic struggle as warfare in which his enemies will not be able to ‘prevail’ over him.
